No longer I'll pipe on the plain,</br>No more will I tune to the Nine:</br>Ah me!  how unhappy a swain!</br>Eliza can never be mine.
In fancy how once was I blest,</br>But, alas!  the delusion is o'er;</br>Tho' lost is the hope I possest,</br>I never shall cease to adore.
She's fair as the opening rose;</br>She's sweet as the jessamine's flow'r;</br>She's soft as the woodbine which grows,</br>Encircling the sweet-scented bow'r.
Oftimes when reclin'd in the shade</br>I've sung in soft notes to her praise,</br>How blest!  if a smile from the maid</br>Has seem'd to approve of my lays.
For her I once rear'd the soft bow'r,</br>For her was alone the design;</br>Within plac'd each redolent flow'r,</br>Around bade the jessamine twine.
No longer reviv'd by her smile,</br>The jessamine droops to the ground;</br>Its verdure has fled from the soil,</br>The flow'rets are fading around.
I'll walk in the dead of the night,</br>Endymion shall light me along;</br>I'll walk when avoiding the light,</br>Sad Nyctimene utters her song.
Oh!  give me the desolate cave,</br>Whence is banish'd the face of the day;</br>Oh!  give me the maddening wave,</br>When tempests their fury display.
Oh!  give me where fancy has made</br>The seat of the phantom and sprite;</br>Oh!  give me the gloom of the shade,</br>Entrancing the horrors of night.
But whilst I'm thus sadly inclin'd,</br>Thus wildly I utter my care;</br>Sweet hope repossesses my mind,</br>Dispelling the gloom of despair.
May some whisp'ring angel impart</br>The passion which reigns in my breast;</br>And, oh!  is she heave but her heart,</br>Then Colin shall truly be blest.</br>
